name: Big Bend National Park
description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and species diversity is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...
shortDescription: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a...

operatingHours.description: Big Bend National Park is always open. You can enter and exit at any time of the day or night. Park entrances are open 24 hours daily, all year.

fees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle
fees.description: Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less); valid for 7 days.

fees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle
fees.description: Valid for 7 days. Admits up to 2 private, non-commercial motorcycles with up to 4 total passengers.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Admits one individual. Typically used for bicyclists and pedestrians; valid for 7 days.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description: Companies conducting business in the park are required to obtain a commercial use authorization. The only exception is companies travelling in a 26-person capacity or greater vehicle; such vehicles are charged a flat fee of $200 (commercial use authorization not required).

fees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups
fees.description:
Organized groups such as Scouts, clubs, etc. that do not qualify for an academic fee waiver are charged as follows:
$30 per non-commercial vehicle with a capacity of 15 or less.
$15 per person traveling in a non-commercial vehicle with a capacity of 16 or more. Fees will not exceed the commercial rate for the same sized vehicle. Youth 15 and younger are free. Individuals or families with a valid annual or lifetime pass may use their pass for themselves and up to 3 others.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus
fees.description:
This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.

https://www.nps.gov/bibe/learn/management/cua.htm

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan
fees.description:
These fees are charged only to commercial organizations, such as tour companies. This fee is determined by the seating capacity of the vehicle. For sedan with 1 to 6 seats, the fee is $30 + $15 per client.
This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.

climate.weatherDescription: Big Bend is in the Chihuahuan Desert. Sunshine is abundant year-round. Spring (March) is typically warm and pleasant and is the park's busiest season. Summer heat begins in May. It is extremely HOT. Temperatures vary greatly between the desert which is usually well above 100 degrees F by late morning, and the Chisos Mountains, which can be 10-15 degrees cooler. May - August are the hottest months. Fall and Winter (Nov-Feb) are mild and pleasant, but some freezing does occur. Snow is rare.

images.title: Blooming Cenizo
images.caption: Cenizo, or Big Bend Silverleaf blossoms after summer rains.

images.title: Century Plant Agave
images.caption: Century Plants bloom only once in their long lives.

images.title: Vermilion Flycatcher
images.caption: Big Bend is home to over 450 species of birds!

images.title: Desert Scenery
images.caption: Big Bend is a prime example of Chihuahuan Desert

images.title: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.altText: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.caption: Big Bend is a place of expansive views

images.title: Rio Grande Scene
images.caption: The Rio Grande serves as the park's southern boundary

images.title: Blooming Ocotillo
images.caption: When ocotillo bloom, they transform the desert

images.title: Balanced Rock
images.caption: The balanced rock is a popular day hiking destination.
